timeline.bodyText: Just use @value as mentioned in previous PR?
timeline.author: chaurah

replies.bodyText: I need a customized constructor, which takes version as string, so internally I can force to use NPM semver type to check.
replies.author: wikimonkey

replies.bodyText: Let me check the customized one will replace the generated one, if yes, I will switch to use @value
replies.author: wikimonkey

replies.bodyText: The customized one doesn't override the generated one, by using @value it will have a constructor than can take Semver, which could be a risk that external can mess up package manager version resolution by specifying different Semver type.
replies.author: wikimonkey

replies.bodyText:
Based on this : https://projectlombok.org/features/Value
"any explicit constructor, no matter the arguments list, implies lombok will not generate a constructor"
Your custom constructor should just prevent @value from generating one
replies.author: chaurah

replies.bodyText:
https://drive.corp.amazon.com/documents/zhengang@/Screen%20Shot%202020-02-25%20at%208.08.52%20PM.png
I changed to use @value with customized constructors. Lombok still generates one I want to avoid.
replies.author: wikimonkey

replies.bodyText: Interesting, that seems different from what the doc implies. Maybe it only applies in case of Lombok generated constructors? Thanks for validating though
replies.author: chaurah

replies.bodyText:
IntelliJ is wrong. Try using the constructor and you'll see that it doesn't compile.
https://drive.corp.amazon.com/documents/mdombro@/public/Screen%20Shot%202020-02-26%20at%2011.20.15%20AM.png
https://drive.corp.amazon.com/documents/mdombro@/public/Screen%20Shot%202020-02-26%20at%2011.20.22%20AM.png
replies.author: MikeDombo

timeline.bodyText: Same as above, use @value and @Setter?
timeline.author: chaurah

replies.bodyText: Value is immutable, if you need a setter, use @data
replies.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: Same reason as above. Customized constructor. Let me make sure lombok behaviors.
replies.author: wikimonkey

replies.bodyText: Lombok works correctly. Use @Data.
replies.author: MikeDombo

timeline.bodyText: Should be final? Any changes during dependency resolution will show up in the output in the final Package object I think.
timeline.author: chaurah

replies.bodyText: During dependency resolution, the version will be re-determined. That's why it's not final. Another approach is to always create new one so to make instance immutable. Since this is package manager internal data object, shouldn't operate in multi-threads env, I think mutating it is ok.
replies.author: wikimonkey

timeline.bodyText: we should still check and make sure the incoming semver is of type npm
timeline.author: chaurah

replies.bodyText: If interface is encapsulated properly, the type is guaranteed in the storing model.
replies.author: wikimonkey

timeline.bodyText: Same questions as above.
timeline.author: chaurah

timeline.bodyText:
[nit]
Remove unnecessary whitespace.
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: will do
replies.author: wikimonkey

timeline.bodyText:
If this doesn't absolute need to be a single thread, then just get an executor using @Inject so that the Context will provide it to you.
Probably all these fields should be final too.
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: Agree. Thread model of PM is not emphasis of this PR. Just choose a way can work. We can come back on this later.
replies.author: wikimonkey

timeline.bodyText: Why is the package manager storing the proposed packages as a field? This would seem to be something which is specific to deployment, and really should not be a field but passed as a parameter.
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: This is to work with Callable. As you can see, public interface is a method taking it as parameter. To execute actual work in another thread, this is one approach. Later we will add guard rails on tracking, handling the asynchronous work.
replies.author: wikimonkey

timeline.bodyText: Can we get a reasonable message here about what is conflicting?
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText:
Let me try to add more comments. The logic needs to handle many cases. I tried to make it concise, so probably need some guidance to the audience.
Here is to say "we want to use proposed package, but is it proposed package version meeting the constraints of all of its dependent?"
replies.author: wikimonkey

timeline.bodyText: Why is this correct? If we're using a new version of a package, why are we pulling the dependencies from the currently installed version?
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: Keep in mind, we now allow one version for one package. For example, StreamManager either 1.0 or 2.0. If we would like to use 2.0, we need to check the packages depend on 1.0 whether they are ok with 2.0, also update their references to SM 2.0
replies.author: wikimonkey

replies.bodyText: Oh, I guess I was confused by the name of dependsBy. Maybe dependedOnBy would be better.
replies.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: Yeah. It's better. I will update.
replies.author: wikimonkey

replies.bodyText: Can you make that rename? The current name is still confusing.
replies.author: MikeDombo

timeline.bodyText: Why is the version null?
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: In the current loop, we haven't determined dependency verison, so version is null. We have decided current processing package version.
replies.author: wikimonkey

timeline.bodyText: Where'd all the comments go? The section above wait more readable. This section is quite tricky and I would benefit greatly from more comments IMO.
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: Please add more comments to this section since we're all agreed that it is confusing.
replies.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: added
replies.author: wikimonkey

timeline.bodyText: All JavaDoc needs two asterisks /**.
timeline.author: MikeDombo

timeline.bodyText: Please add JavaDoc to all public interfaces.
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: Will add
replies.author: wikimonkey

timeline.bodyText: Might be better to just store the entire package object after resolution based on the whiteboard discussion
timeline.author: chaurah

replies.bodyText: Entire package including lifecycle, artifact URL seems too much to me. There is no reason to do that now I think.
replies.author: wikimonkey

timeline.bodyText: Return is being ignored here
timeline.author: chaurah

replies.bodyText: Yes, I will add a TODO on what we would like to do here. I can think of many things, from simply one fail all fail to partial success deployment. The 1st version we can fail it if not all the things downloaded.
replies.author: wikimonkey

timeline.bodyText: Based on the incoming request, devicePackages is actually the active packages currently on device right? Not the full contents of the cache?
timeline.author: chaurah

replies.bodyText: It is active packages registered in package registry. Their recipes and artifacts should also be cached. Source of truth is package registry.
replies.author: wikimonkey

timeline.bodyText: Since these are PackageRegistry related, do you think some of this can be abstracted out and moved into the package registry? It feels like this method is doing too much bookkeeping in addition to the resolution. I think it should be easier to read if it just did resolution and then let the registry update the DB for bookkeeping.
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText:
The principle I use is to separate control with data flow. Since the dependency resolution is control logic. I would rather have them out of data model, so the data don't carry handling logic.
I agree this method is heavy. Probably we can think of refactoring to smaller sub-methods.
replies.author: wikimonkey

replies.bodyText:
This isn't control flow though, you're doing data manipulations here, which is why I suggested moving it to the registry class. At this point, the control is basically done since you know what version of that package you'll be using.
Also you told me earlier that that PackageRegistryEntry and Reference were only for the database, so why should the package manager be manipulating these data objects? It seems that that job should be handled only by the package registry.
replies.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText:
I can see your reasoning. IMO it's still control flow. It's continuing data manipulation logic after deciding current package version, update its dependencies and dependents. It includes inter instances operations, not only instance internal operations.
Use the analogy in the cloud service, PackageRegistryEntry is business model, it's not necessary to persist data by that model (although most likely we will just serialize this model for now), we usually convert to physical data model when coming to storage. But neither business model nor storage model need to contain handling logic of the other instances.
replies.author: wikimonkey
fengwang666

replies.bodyText: :) I don't deny this block is obscure. It spends me a ton of time thinking of the logic. I am welcome to refactor on this with proper encapsulation, divide to sub processes etc. But before doing that, I plan to add a ton of unit test cases to validate this pieces of logic. If it proves to be working, we can leverage the test cases when doing refactoring.
replies.author: wikimonkey

timeline.bodyText: Why adding final? Our code style guidelines say to keep things as non-final unless it is a risk. Do you think there's a risk here?
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: I mark it final in order to make it not inheritable. If package manager doesn't contain state itself, having child is not necessary, only degrade code readability.
replies.author: wikimonkey

replies.bodyText: Remove the final. It should be open to subclassing for future expansion.
replies.author: MikeDombo

timeline.bodyText: nit: ...List -> ...Map?
timeline.author: fengwang666

replies.bodyText: package registry interface return list. Convert to map for operation convenience.
replies.author: wikimonkey

replies.bodyText: We could names it just activePackages, the declaration already tells you what type it is
replies.author: shaguptashaikh

replies.bodyText: sure
replies.author: wikimonkey

timeline.bodyText: Not sure if this condition will actually occur.
timeline.author: fengwang666

replies.bodyText: It won't now. But could when it connects with cloud. TODO is for reconsidering how to handle partial failure cases.
replies.author: wikimonkey

timeline.bodyText: Would anyone outside package manager need to know how the registry is initialized? If not we could initialize that inline here instead of having a constructor do it?
timeline.author: shaguptashaikh

replies.bodyText: You are right, probably not. This is mainly for unit test mocking. We could create static factory method to properly initialize the instances.
replies.author: wikimonkey

replies.bodyText: This should be @Injected.
replies.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: As Shagupta's pointing out, package registry and package store are internal to package manager. I think a static factory method to initialize the instances are more appropriate instead of relying on external inject.
replies.author: wikimonkey

timeline.bodyText: Is this modifying activePackageList? It's not very clear on this line
timeline.author: shaguptashaikh

replies.bodyText: Yes, it's updating the map.
replies.author: wikimonkey

timeline.bodyText: If beforePackageSet was initialized with all values in activePackageList then pendingDownloadPackages on this line will always be empty, unless activePackageList is modified inside resolveDependencies. This may be working this way but it's confusing to read
timeline.author: shaguptashaikh

replies.bodyText: Since the map is modified during dependency resolution, so the new package will be added.
replies.author: wikimonkey

timeline.bodyText:
This will fail even if the dependsOnBy is also updated in the new deployment.
ex
current version:
A 1.0 depends on  C 1.0
B 1.0 depende on  C 1.0
new deployment updates C 1.0 to C 2.0 and updates both A and B to use C 2.0.  The new deployment should not fail as both A and B updated the dependency on C, but as per this logic it will fail.
timeline.author: fahadmohammed01

timeline.bodyText: None of our other classes do this. Use our injection framework like everyone else unless there's a very good reason not to.
timeline.author: MikeDombo

timeline.message: change to return set instead of map
